channel.title: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: News Out Of Eastern Ukraine Battle Zone Is Hard To Confirm
item.description: The Ukrainian army insists pro-Moscow separatists attacked a civilian convoy on Monday, killing at least 17 civilians. Rebels deny the attack took place.
item.content:encoded:
The Ukrainian army insists pro-Moscow separatists attacked a civilian convoy on Monday, killing at least 17 civilians. Rebels deny the attack took place.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson

item.title: Other Hostages Are In Danger, White House Official Says.
item.description: Kelly McEvers talks to Ben Rhodes, President Obama's deputy national security advisor, about White House foreign policy following the brutal killing of an American journalist by Islamist militants.
item.content:encoded:
Kelly McEvers talks to Ben Rhodes, President Obama's deputy national security advisor, about White House foreign policy following the brutal killing of an American journalist by Islamist militants.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Why Civil Resistance Movements Work
item.description: Steve Inskeep talks to Erica Chenoweth and Maria Stephan about why non-violent resistance campaigns work better than armed rebellion. Their article on the subject is in Foreign Affairs magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Steve Inskeep talks to Erica Chenoweth and Maria Stephan about why non-violent resistance campaigns work better than armed rebellion. Their article on the subject is in Foreign Affairs magazine.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Foley's Murder By Islamist Militants Shocks World's Conscience, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama says the civilized world is appalled by the tactics of those who killed journalist James Foley, and he urged people in the Middle East to resist the group's "bankrupt ideology."
item.content:encoded:
President Obama says the civilized world is appalled by the tactics of those who killed journalist James Foley, and he urged people in the Middle East to resist the group's "bankrupt ideology."

» E-Mail This

item.title: Islamic State Uses Online Strategies To Get Its Message Out
item.description: Experts say the videotaped killing of journalist James Foley is part of a broader propaganda strategy by Islamist militants. The group, the Islamic State, has become a master of the video medium.
item.content:encoded:
Experts say the videotaped killing of journalist James Foley is part of a broader propaganda strategy by Islamist militants. The group, the Islamic State, has become a master of the video medium.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Dina Temple-Raston

item.title: B.K.S. Iyenagar Dies At 95. Sickly Child Became Yoga Guru
item.description: Commentator Sandip Roy has an appreciation of yogi B.K.S. Iyengar, who died on Wednesday. Iyengar helped to introduce the practice of yoga to the Western world.
item.content:encoded:
Commentator Sandip Roy has an appreciation of yogi B.K.S. Iyengar, who died on Wednesday. Iyengar helped to introduce the practice of yoga to the Western world.

» E-Mail This

item.title: How Syria's Assad Has Managed To Hold On To Power
item.description: Kelly McEvers talks to Syria expert Shashank Joshi, about President Bashar al-Assad's tenacious grip on power. Joshi is with the Royal Services Institute in London.
item.content:encoded:
Kelly McEvers talks to Syria expert Shashank Joshi, about President Bashar al-Assad's tenacious grip on power. Joshi is with the Royal Services Institute in London.

» E-Mail This

item.title: U.S. Reveals Failed Special Forces Mission To Rescue Hostages
item.description: The Obama administration's admission comes on the heels of the release of a video by the militant group known as the Islamic State, which depicts the killing of American journalist James Foley.
item.content:encoded:
The Obama administration's admission comes on the heels of the release of a video by the militant group known as the Islamic State, which depicts the killing of American journalist James Foley.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Audie Cornish

item.title: No. 1 Most Expensive Coffee Comes From Elephant's No. 2
item.description: A coffee entrepreneur claims his brew is different — and better — than the trendy civet poop coffee. And it starts with the idea that elephants, unlike humans or civets, are herbivores.
item.content:encoded:
A coffee entrepreneur claims his brew is different — and better — than the trendy civet poop coffee. And it starts with the idea that elephants, unlike humans or civets, are herbivores.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Michael Sullivan

item.title: In Syria, The U.S. Weighs A Range Of Unpalatable Options
item.description: The U.S. could aid moderate rebels. It could bomb militants of the Islamic State. Or it could sit on the sidelines as the war plays out. There are many choices, but none appears promising.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. could aid moderate rebels. It could bomb militants of the Islamic State. Or it could sit on the sidelines as the war plays out. There are many choices, but none appears promising.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Michele Kelemen

item.title: Militants Behead American Journalist, Leveling New Threats At U.S.
item.description: The group known as the Islamic State has fired its first violent salvo against the U.S. The group declared that the beheading is a retaliation for U.S. airstrikes in Iraq.
item.content:encoded:
The group known as the Islamic State has fired its first violent salvo against the U.S. The group declared that the beheading is a retaliation for U.S. airstrikes in Iraq.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Dina Temple-Raston

item.title: In Liberia, An Ebola Quarantine Descends Into Riots
item.description: After the Liberian government ordered a quarantine of one of the poorest neighborhoods in its capital, Monrovia, residents there woke up to find themselves cut off from the rest of the city by security forces. By midday, the neighborhood was in riot.
item.content:encoded:
After the Liberian government ordered a quarantine of one of the poorest neighborhoods in its capital, Monrovia, residents there woke up to find themselves cut off from the rest of the city by security forces. By midday, the neighborhood was in riot.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Nurith Aizenman

item.title: Gaza Violence Tests Once-Unshakable Allies U.S. And Israel
item.description: Both sides have traded barbs and criticism over the other's policies. Some believe the public feud stems from a personal animosity between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.content:encoded:
Both sides have traded barbs and criticism over the other's policies. Some believe the public feud stems from a personal animosity between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Jackie Northam

item.title: The Ice Bucket Challenge And Other Good Causes: Do Stars Really Help?
item.description: When actor Tom Hiddleston and Lady Gaga take the Ice Bucket Challenge, it makes a big splash. But do stars really make a difference in fund-raising and public awareness when they endorse a charity?
item.content:encoded:
When actor Tom Hiddleston and Lady Gaga take the Ice Bucket Challenge, it makes a big splash. But do stars really make a difference in fund-raising and public awareness when they endorse a charity?

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Roff Smith

item.title: Photographing An Ebola Riot: Put Your Fear Aside And Go Forward
item.description: Covering protests over an Ebola quarantine, NPR photographer David Gilkey found himself in the middle of a riot. He says he doesn't know what was scarier — the bullets or the health risks.
item.content:encoded:
Covering protests over an Ebola quarantine, NPR photographer David Gilkey found himself in the middle of a riot. He says he doesn't know what was scarier — the bullets or the health risks.
